perturbation.original_text: 11.7 If your employment is terminated on account of your death or by the Company without Cause (being for any reason not covered by paragraph 11.3), or you terminate your employment for Good Reason (as provided in paragraph 11.4), in either case outside of the Change in Control Period, then the Company shall pay you the Accrued Benefits. In addition, subject to (i) your (or your authorised representative or estate signing, if the termination is due to your death) signing a settlement agreement and a separation agreement and release (together the "Settlement Agreements") in a form and manner satisfactory to the Company, which shall include, without limitation, a general release of claims against the Company and all related persons and entities, a reaffirmation of all of your continuing obligations to the Company, including those set forth in paragraphs 13 - 15, and (in the case of the separation agreement and release) and a seven (7) business day revocation period; and (ii) the separation agreement and release becoming irrevocable, all within 60 days after the Termination Date (or such shorter period as set forth in the Settlement Agreements), the Company shall: (A) pay you (or your authorised representative or estate if the termination is due to your death) an amount equal to nine (9) months of your salary as of the Termination Date (which payment shall not be reduced by either the value of any salary paid to you during your notice period or by any payment in lieu of notice made pursuant to paragraph 11.2); and (B) pay you (or your authorised representative or estate if the termination is due to your death) an amount equal to the cost to the Company of providing you with the contractual benefits under paragraph 5 for nine (9) months or, at the Company's option, continue to provide you with such benefits for nine (9) months.

perturbation.explanation: Moving the severance pay terms to a section on outside employment obscures the terms of termination. Employees would typically look for severance details in the 'Notice' or 'Termination' sections, not under 'Outside Employment'. The United Kingdom's Employment Rights Act 1996 requires employers to provide clear written particulars of employment, and obscuring this information violates that requirement.

perturbation.explanation: Moving the restrictive covenants to after the data protection clause. This means that a reader might miss these terms and not give it proper weight, because the subject has shifted. A reader might be less likely to read the restrictive covenants because they just reviewed the privacy policy of the company. A UK court requires restrictive convenants to be brought to the attention of the employee.
